comments.commentBody: Conservatives have blamed the 2008 financial crisis on the government making loans to folks who couldn't afford them. Will they reconsider their positions in light of the JP Morgan fiasco? Similarly, they refuse to learn from the failures of the austerity measures in Europe. The conservative movement is like a spring that has been winding up for 3 decades, and now nothing will stop it from the detente. No new facts, no new evidence will change that. The only way to stop this nonsense is with a force equal and opposite.

The bankers simply do not have the capacity to regulate themselves. Power and greed are their creed, and the public good is irrelevant. What is needed are criminal repercussions that will send individuals to institutions where they will be very uncomfortable, for a very long period of time.. Staying ahead of these folks is not easy. Perhaps, the FBI could train gifted agents to infiltrate the banking system, after all, it is a matter of national security.

Dimon is chairman of the Board of Directors of the NY Fed. Elizabeth Warren has called for his resignation. To my knowledge, his term is due to expire this year anyway. More here:

http://livewire.talkingpointsmemo.com/entries/warren-calls-on-dimon-to-r...
Forget protecting the industry and start protecting the public.

Assuming that the comment that Chase's Mr. Dimon is indeed president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank is true, we must demand his resignation from the Federal Reserve Bank. These powerful, influential positions must be held by persons who are trying to create a financial system that promotes competition within strong rules that protect the industry. Just like the NBA, NFL and MLB. Thank goodness I have moved my "banking" to a credit union that actually follows some simple rules.

The only way to take control is to "vote with your feet" and leave these Banks.  The answer to consumer banking is credit unions which are held outside the commercial sphere.  The answer to commercial banking is ending the cartels and prohibit banking across state lines.  The need for "international"  banks can be met by specialized institution not in local commerce.  No insurance company involvement; no brokerage involvement and real salaries not giveaways to suits -- you get nothing coming in and nothing going out.

That so many critical of big banking have not moved to a credit union by now explains a lot about what is wrong with this country.

They haven't even figured out that the credit unions are a much better deal all the way around. Remarkably Nice.

Back in the early 20th century when Americans learned of the unsanitary conditions in the meat packing industry and the fact that meat was hitting the butcher's shop that had rat feces and dead insects. When the FDA was created and the Meat Inspection Act went into effect, large meat packers supported the new regulations because they knew these measures would bring confidence to their customers and increase sales.

American bankers need to have the wisdom of the meat packers. If they continue to refuse regulations they will continue to lose customers. JPMorgan would be wise to publicly support the Dodd-Frank Act and demonstrate its compliance with all the regulations. If banks don't do this and we have another announcement of big losses all those "sophisticated" investors will turn to Treasury bonds as the only safe place to put their money. Already the small savers like me are turning to credit unions for our banking needs.

Regulations are good for any business that depends on consumer confidence. Banks are no exception.

This is a perfect example why the banking regulation needs go much further than it is being prescribed by Dodd-Frank. The so called "Volcker Rule" bans only certain types of prop trading, which means that banks will try to disguise their trades and claim it is a "hedge" as JP Morgan did on this occasion. If it really was a hedge, where is the profit on the underlying position which should have shown big gains ?

JP Morgan's derivative book is over 50Trillion in notional value. It doesn't matter how smart the management at JP Morgan claims. A govt. insured bank shouldn't be allowed to hold such ridiculous quantities of financial WMDs.

Reinstate Glass-Steagall. Ban most derivatives and put the rest on an exchange. Raise Capital Requirements well beyond Basel III stipulation.

I don't understand your comment. How many black and Hispanic children were involved in any terrorist attacks since 9/11, related to Al Qaeda or otherwise? Why do these youngsters comprise 41% of "furtively moving" suspicious individuals being stopped and searched? Quality of life searches and hunting for terrorists require two separate cadres of police. The "furtive movements" are an obvious sign of fear in the young people because they know they are being targeted based on their skin color and it makes them feel ashamed—I've watched these sorts of things happen. And the residents of the lily-white high rent districts never seem to have to worry about being stopped and searched, which may wind up being a sure way for a real terrorist to find a place in those neighborhoods to live. It's always the devil you don't know. This has got to stop.

Improper use of power by the government has a lot more potential to harm the average person than "terrorizers". "Terrorizers" are vanishingly rare, yet government (and now, corporate) power is everywhere. Far more Americans died in the pointless wars in Iraq and Afghansitan than in 9/11. Not to mention the civilian casualties in those nations. Centers of government power have taken a blank check from the 9/11 attacks to vastly expand their powers using "Terrorizers" as the excuse/justification, far beyond anything that is warranted. The whole body scanners are another example of this. The vast majority of the planet (and even the US) do not use these things and there have not been any "Terrorizer" attacks exploiting this supposed "vulnerability". The "Terrorizers", when, in rare cases, they actually exist, can work around such measures. The real purpose of most of the ramped up "Securitoid" measures after 9/11 are simply a means of renegotiating the power relationship between government and the populace, nothing more. So that people carrying marijuana or with outstanding arrest warrants can be caught. They started checking photo ID for purchasing train tickets. For what the heck purpose? Someone will hijack a train? The fact that people could travel on Amtrak without showing photo ID is trumped up as a "security hole". I dont consider it a "security hole" for it to be possible for a person to travel from one place to another without being tracked by the government.

The situation with the police existed pre-9/11, although since that time NYers have indeed been treated to all sorts of ramping up of shows of force and surveillance.

I know young men who have been the victims of stop and frisk, and they are good kids who did not deserve the rough treatment they received.

My assistant Derrick was walking to the train to meet me for work early in the morning - about 3 a.m. He passed a group of black youth spread eagles against the wall, held by a few policemen. They gestured to him to join the line-up. He said" I don't know those guys, I am going to work." "At this time of the morning? Get on the wall"

So, I was ticked off that he was late, and more ticked off that he didn't want to tell me why. And by the time the story came out, at the end of a long day, I was so outraged and enraged ,and filled with awe at his self-restraint to be able to go on with his day, only a little grumpy, after what had been done to him.

What must our young people be forced to endure as we call upon them to reach high, only to be slapped down so unfairly?

btw - 8 huge cops beat up my smallish 62 year old suit & tie wearing, briefcase carrying grey hair w/ bald spot professor cousin for walking on the wrong side of a parade barrier, blocks from the site. If you think light skin will save you with the NYPD these days, think again. And remember how much worse it is for our youngsters & neighbors of color.

Just after 9-11, and seeing those horrendous scenes over and over, I think like many Americans I felt traumatized. Not long after, I spent time in a small little town in the West, and was struck by the appearance of floodlights at night around a small grocery store/gas station where there had not been any before. We were so far from a big city, yet the fear there was palpable and there was also an unquestioning trust in our authorities at the time to do what was best to protect us. This was at the time when we as a nation were unsure if even more planes would strike in the days to follow.

As New York was the epicenter of this, it is understandable that there is an urgency to hopefully prevent something like that from every happening again. Out of that time has also come significant restrictions to freedom, personal rights and liberties. Many now are saying that the reaction is disproportionate to the now in which we live. It's my view that this lingering suspicion, fear of those we don't know and what they may perpetrate, which has caused such policies as 'stop and frisk' and partly may explain the even more onerous Supreme Court decision allowing for a strip search of any person for any perceived or suspected illegal act.

It is important that we bring balance and sanity back with police searches, so that people who are innocent are not harassed. Do any of us want to live in a state of constant fear from our own authorities?

Effective regulation of derivatives is required to prevent these multi-billion dollar losses. Our economic system is vulnerable to serious damage until prudent regulations are put into place.

We need to take the billion dollar roulette tables out of the banks.

Some would call it "terrorism lite"--inasmuch as people are merely beaten with billy clubs, faces smashed into the pavement, subjected to neck-crushing "knee-takedowns," capsicum spray, etc. Most of it non-lethal.
Show me a "foiled terrorist plot" that does not involve, as a key "plotter," someone from the FBI, CIA, NSA, etc. or one of their "assets" (i.e., DEpendent contractors) and I'll bake you a flan. We could graph these "foiled plot" gambits along with polls that take a read on hysteria/terror/fear levels, to see if there's a correlation between "faltering fear/diminishing terror" levels and the "foiled plots." That is, reduced terror triggers "foiled plots."
More to the point: Let's have an echt/real criminal investigation into 9/11/2001, before, during and after the day. As independent citizens continue to investigate 9/11 on their own and bring forward all the evidence ignored by the makers and keepers of The Official Myth, it's clearer that 9/11/2001 was the most successful--and brilliant-- False Flag Operation in all of world history. We should give Oscars, or gilt Guy Fawkes face masks (Fawkesies) to the lead players. Who'll win for FX, I wonder?

From everything I have read and seen, the City of New York is operated as a personal fiefdom by Mayor Bloomberg, and what he has jocularly called his "private army." Mark Thomason is right -- there have been more NYPD stops of black men than there are black men living in New York. Even in the Jim Crow South, pre-Civil Rights, there was nothing like this.

Where is the Justice Department and where is the State Attorney General? For that matter, what about that investigation that was supposed to target NYPD spying on the entire Muslim community? Oh, that's right -- the U.S counter-terrorism honcho, John Brennan, was just in town to applaud the Bloomberg administration for doing a heckuva job. Stopping, and frisking, and spying on all those darker-hued folks keeps us safe, so they say. And don't forget the many people being caught up in the Obama Administration's "Secure Communities" immigration dragnet, either.

They claim they're trying to keep us safe. What they're succeeding at is keeping us in a constant state of fear, and keeping the Banking/Prison/Homeland Security complex in business.

Tell me about it. Deregulation and the "too big to fail" problem has been with us for quite some time. What should still be relatively recent memory often fails to illuminate a pattern or common threat. Enron. WorldCom. Arthur Anderson. Jack Abramoff, The S&L crisis. We've been there, done that. This is precisely the problem --- everybody is joining the fray from different angles, some of whom account for the lessons of the past and some of whom have already forgotten last month's news. (MF Global...) It is difficult to build public and political consensus --- the will to fix anything --- when memories are short and grapevines longer by the day. As voters and "stewards of democracy" the only way to avoid acting as an unwitting parrots of misinformation, media bias and propaganda is to allow the chips fall where they may --- whether it flatters members of one's party or not. My 2 cents, for what it's worth: Do one's homework --- due diligence to the issues and concerns --- and modify one's opinions accordingly.

I feel for you. I was born fat, too, and I now take antidepressants that make losing weight nigh-on impossible. I've gotten my BMI down to 29 and held it there for almost two years, which feels like a miracle at this point. I eat very little, and when "weight loss drugs" promise that they will work I laugh...they work because they suppress your appetite. I don't NEED to suppress my appetite, I already restrict my calories enough!

I've had some luck with Mac's suggestion: primal eating. I certainly FEEL better eating primal and I haven't gained weight doing it. I wish I had another option, but just wanted to say that I really sympathize with your post.
